abstract.p: Joel M Woldman letter on June 21 article notes Lea & Perrin sauce is simply called Worcester sauce in Britain; complains ingredients are not same around world

block.p: I just finished reading R. W. Apple Jr.'s delightful and informative article (''Toque and Dagger: The Sauce Secrets of Worcester,'' June 21). I was surprised he didn't mention that at least in Britain, the sauce is called simply Worcester (pronounced wooster) sauce, even though the label reads Worcestershire Sauce. It's a lot easier to say.

I just finished reading R. W. Apple Jr.'s delightful and informative article (''Toque and Dagger: The Sauce Secrets of Worcester,'' June 21). I was surprised he didn't mention that at least in Britain, the sauce is called simply Worcester (pronounced wooster) sauce, even though the label reads Worcestershire Sauce. It's a lot easier to say.

And sadly, the ingredients are not the same the world over. I was disgusted to find on my latest bottle of Lea & Perrins, made in Fair Lawn, N.J., that sugar has been dispensed with in favor of high-fructose corn syrup, a substitution that makes products traditionally prepared with pure sugar less bright in taste. Fortunately, the American-made Lea & Perrins still tastes pretty good. JOEL M. WOLDMAN Alexandria, Va.
